Physics is at the center of every mystery in the universe. One of those mysteries is who in their right mind would put me in charge of bridge construction, or you? reviewText:
Early Access Review

IntroductionPoly Bridge is a game currently in Early Access and it merges two genres (puzzles and simulation) into one seamless, addictive experience. I’ve seen (and played) plenty of games like this before, starting years ago actually, but somehow there always seems to be room for improvement. So here we have the big question: does Poly Bridge bring anything new to the table? And can it be enjoyed if this is your very first time playing such a game?

GameplayI will begin by answering these questions first and will get to the more detailed analysis later.
No, the game doesn’t bring anything *truly* new to the table, but it does manage to improve upon (quite) a few aspects and all of these improvements definitely make the game more fun. The result of this is that anyone, new or experienced, can play this game with relative ease.
Poly Bridge is just one of those games that makes you want to try again and again just to see if you can get better results or to see if you can build something the way you imagine(d). Granted, at first you’ll be limited to the game’s tools and therefore you won’t have access to everything just yet, but even with a limited toolset you can build brilliant bridge constructions.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=524290369
To be fair: the goal of the game is to build a bridge with as little money as possible (i.e. keep it below the budget) but the game still allows you to continue if you exceed this budget, as long as the vehicles have passed the flag. That, in my opinion, is an excellent way to pull in all kinds of players; you’re free to do whatever you want as long as you’re able to create and finish a solid construction. In fact, you can choose which level you want to play (almost) right from the start. There’s no set ‘story’ to follow.

The downside to this design choice is that the ‘true’ goal of the game (build a bridge with limited resources and money) gets lost somehow; it becomes kind of a secondary, optional, objective and I’m not sure if that’s the intention of the developer.
Sure, the main goal is to get the vehicles across the bridge, but let’s face it; the vehicles need to get across anyway. In order to do that you need to build a solid bridge in the first place. So the way I see it it’s some sort of secondary objective, really.
Still, I like it the way it is currently handled and I’m sure there are many others that share that sentiment, but I just wanted to address it for a bit. Please keep in mind that it’s my point of view and you might feel different about it.

The interface is easy and intuitive: in the top left corner you have your usual menu, in the top center you have your budget and available resources (among other things) and in the top right you have the simulation controls that starts or stops the… em, simulation.
Now, to start building you just middle-click on the screen and you can then select your tools from a radial menu. Right-clicking deletes and item and holding and dragging the right-click button lets you delete multiple objects at the same time. This works extremely well and it’s actually a joy to use, especially if a large part of your construction needs to be revised. Left-clicking obviously places the objects that you selected on the screen. Basically that’s all there is to it. It’s one of the easiest editors I’ve even seen.
Finally, the building part is done from a 2D perspective, seen from the side, and it’s great to see your bridge come to life in 3D when you eventually run the simulation (where you can also move the camera more freely).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=524290418
As we know the game is still being worked on, so we can expect more levels and features to be added in the future, but for now there’s more than enough content to keep you occupied for hours. Finishing levels will also unlock new vehicles for use in future levels. Actually, once you unlock a vehicle it’s almost always used in the very next level. And while they aren’t true collectibles it’s still a nice way to keep players interested and they add a bit of a challenge for the levels to come (because of the weight, of course).

All-in all I’m very impressed with the build so far. I’m happy to say that it’s also being actively worked on and updates appear regularly.

Audio & VisualsThere’s not much to say about the audio; it’s a bit repetitive, but other than that it’s relaxing and non-obtrusive. It didn’t make me want to turn my volume off, which sometimes happens with other, similar, games. So, for that: bonus points!
The visuals of the game are amazingly beautiful. They’re low polygon and they have just the right amount of detail. It’s a nice combination of cartoony graphics and realistic objects. See it in motion and you’ll understand what I mean.
Sometimes the physics get a bit messed up (mostly because of collision detection) and so far I haven’t encountered any gamebreaking bugs, but do they affect the graphics. Parts of the objects just get relocated to a different position of that same object then, or ‘break off’ altogether. Still, it all worked fine for me personally, but it did detract from the experience. But I guess you have these sort of bugs and glitches in almost every physics system nowadays. It’s nothing noteworthy really, but still should be mentioned in case you expect a bug-free game here (which you should never expect, to be honest).
Overall, nothing to complain here. Nothing but clean and stylish graphics.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=524290387
Length/Replay ValueThe replay value for this game is amazing. You have a GIF creator that lets you save your simulations to GIF format. Also, Steam Workshop has already been implemented so that we can share all of our amazing creations with each other and, of course, this can not be done without the level editor, which is naturally also already included in this Early Access version.
Potentially, you could play this game over and over again, just to beat your previous scores/budgets. In a way it’s endless (but in reality it’s not). Still, damn good value.

ConclusionPoly Bridge is an amazing game for young and old. It’s still needs a little work: right now it can be seen as a diamond in the rough, but I’m confident it will be fully polished by the time it releases, somewhere later this year.
I have nothing bad to say at all about the gameplay, which is fun and invites you to try out different things. I do have some questions about some of the design choices, though, but fortunately these are kept to a minimum. It’s absolutely worth the current asking price.

A fairly fun bridge building sim that makes failing almost as fun as succeeding. Some bugs but overall a good stable game.

The current early access version does feature the majority of the campaign mode. In the campaign you go through different landscapes known as worlds. Each world has several levels that increase in difficultly and complexity as you go along. The also has a sandbox mode where you can create your own levels, play them and export them online for others to play as well as playing other peoples yourself.

The premise behind each level in the game is simple, build a stable enough bridge over the water to allow a variety of vehicles to get across using the whatever building resources your given and remaining under budget. It’s a simple concept that in execution becomes a lot more difficult as you progress. Difficulty progression is key in a puzzle based game and Poly Bridge does it quite well.

There’s plenty of content to get into in the early access build, Poly Bridge is a well-built little game that would also be good for kids. It’s the kind of game that hints at what games could potentially do for education, in this case maths and engineering. One very gimmicky feature of the game is the ability to save replays of your epic bridge failures or wins as sharable GIFS that you can send direct to your social media. The game gives you the space to have plenty of creative flair but is fairly limited in terms of scope at this point however the developers are planning on expanding the game further with more content.

If you’re interested in the game you’ll get your monies worth in early access and since there will be no price difference between this version and the full launch version it’s a case of picking it up when you want.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a really fun and stimulating simulator. The physics is realistic enough to feel right and the levels are well-designed scenarios with a well-tapered learning curve. The game gives you enough freedom to do it right and while giving enough incentives to get creative and cut corners where you can. I'd love for all engineers to play this game as training.

I also can't rave enough about the artistic design here. The color palette, the artistic style and the music all go together beautifully to create a kind of Americana-cute aesthetic that works surprisingly well for this kind of game. It has a very 50s/early 60s vibe to it, like a tribute to a bygone era.

This is early access though and there are some areas for continuing improvement. The general control scheme is good, but there are some missing options and features (like a simulation pause button!). You'll also come across bugs and unrefined bits, but none of this should dissuade you from buying this one now. I usually avoid early access for a number of reasons, but the core gameplay here is completely ready for users, and the developers have been good about responding to feedback.

In short, if you like puzzles, physics & strategy games, or ever had fun building a popsicle-stick bridge, buy this game TODAY. You won't regret it.

Poly Bridge is awesome! The design is cute and very simple but building bridges can get extremely complicated. The physics of the game is on point and every single part you build affects it. If you decide to put 2 wooden parts under a 30 degree angle and the road under a 20 degree angle while using half of the max length of the parts, you will end up with a completely different thing in case you decide to put a slightly longer wood or road part.

Building a functional bridge is easy at start, you can probably finish the first 10 bridges of the campaign in 20 minutes but then it gets insane, there are a few bridges that will take you literally hours to figure out. One wrong cable connection, a tiny mistake of placing a wood part can ruin your entire bridge and make you go insane.

The first 2 worlds too me 6 hours the first time and 2 hours the second time to complete. The game now has a third world too that I still haven't checked out.
It also has Sandbox where you can build your own bridges and share them on Steam workshop. It is still a bit buggy but hey, sandbox didn't exist a week ago so in 2 months I bet we will have a billion community created bridges in a very good sandbox mode!
You can also automatically share your bridge wins and fails over Twitter which is pretty cool too!

Poly Bridge is an addictive and surprisingly complicated game about getting a car from A to B.  Or getting two cars from A to B. Towards each other. Or jumping cars across a river and just hoping the bridge doesn't fall down.  I went in not expecting much and got a lot of entertainment out of Poly Bridge. :D

You get a wide assortment of building materials to use and it's really up to you how you make them achieve the goal set for any given level.  Your only limitation is your imagination... and your budget... and whatever material caps may be in place to keep things interesting.

The look of this game is really sharp and cartoony and the music is wonderful.  The way the game seamlessly transitions from build to action mode it worth mentioning it looks super good.

Don't let the tutorial fool you the later levels will have you rack your brain trying to win.  See my first real challenge level here in all it's frustrating glory: https://youtu.be/2kMyaFiG0Tk

There's nothing like a good bridge building simulator to awaken the civil engineer inside of me. It's one of the few genres that allows me to be creative, giving the freedom to eschew the more obvious solution and allowing my mind to come up with something truly innovative. Polybridge, from the developers at Dry Cactus, takes a lighthearted approach to a sometimes sterile genre, tasking the player with building crossings for a variety of different vehicles from a limited selection of construction tools.

The game kicks off with a handy tutorial, detailing the various building parts, from standard wood beams and iron girders, to the more exotic suspension cables and hydraulic pistons. Each mission has its own budget and set of tools that you must use so, while there is a degree of freedom to be had, you won't be building that multistory crossing with hydraulic lifts over a ten foot gap!

Initially, you'll be tasked with building  crossings for mopeds and family cars - simple stuff, like transporting vehicles from point A" to point "B". From there on

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been working on a more comprehensive review, but looking through the ones already available, I feel as though I don't need to go into depth about game mechanics.

To start, here's a short list of my personal Pros and Cons.

Pros:
- The physics are fantastic
- The game gets rather challenging fairly quickly, but never seems to give an unfair challenge
- With the construction system, on most of the levels there's room for an extremely large ammount of Creativity. (Notice I said Most. I'll get to that later.)
- The soundtrack is relaxing, and this is one of the few games I would buy a soundtrack for (Also will mention this later)
- Customer Suport is extremely good.

Cons:
- Like I mentioned previously, most of the levels offer room for Creativity. Unfortunately, there are a handful of levels that ristrict so many of the peices that there's only a few ways to complete the level. These are by far the worst part of the game.


The game itself, despite the small quantity of poor levels, is extremely fun to play. I'd spent over 10 hours playing the game when my save got deleted, but I enjoy the game enough to replay throught the game again.

When I recently started playing the game again, I had some technical issues that were causing my music to create constant popping noises. Long story short, I couldn't fix the audio due to unrelated issues with my PC, and ultimately couldn't play the game with music. When the creator saw my forums post, one of them added me (Christian_Akacro), and gave me a free copy of the sound track to use while playing the game.

Looking through the forums a bit, the creator seem to be extremely active, and seems to respond to any and all messages he can. I really appreciate the effort that's been but into the game and the community, especially considering that it was independantly created.

To sum up everything, the game is extremely well polished, and is pretty much exactly what the trailers make it look like.

9/10, worth playing through

Early Access Review

http://www.dsr07gaming.com/videogames/poly-bridge-review/

It looks like a classic bridge building game buried under many unsuccessful titles in this genre. But once when you try it you might get positive vibes.

On sight very simple but yet original and fun sandbox game with very solid mechanics where your mind comes on first place with creativity and sneaky fixing of constructions just to be enough to get success. Make possible for multiple vehicles to cross canyons, water, ships or even balloons from point A to point B with less budget and items as further as you go.

You will most of the time be limited with budget as its mentioned along with extra items as metal, hydraulics or cables which will cost more then regular road or wood. There are currently 3 different worlds containing 12 levels each where challenges will become harder and they will require more creativity since you will encounter multiple ships or even vehicles which will depend one on another to make both reach their goal point.

Very well planned and created interface with quick remove/add ability will alleviate rage caused by fixing one weak point while you make couple more during progress.

You can always go through test phase where you can speedup or extremely slow down real time event over your bridge and spot weak points caused by vehicle weight highlighted from green, yellow to red colour until bridge doesnt collapse on those places. Physics are solid comparing to mayority of similiar games and it’s not random so once when you do it, you know what you need to fix, atleast in theory.

Only imagination and well, budget is limit of your creation, from most simple to most complex solutions so everyone have their own way of making ride possible. Art style along with very relaxing and cool music will keep you relaxed and addicted to game despite rage and not being able to make your perfect planned bridge so overall game is fairly balanced in all aspects.

Oh yes, did I mentioned that you can save and share your replays as GIF’s ?

PRO's
+ ART Style
+ Gameplay
+ Physics
+ Replays
+ Level Creator

CON's
- Minor issues with GIF replays

Early Access Review

As an avid player of various 'Bridge Building' games, (yes, it seems to be its own genere)  I must say, of all the entrys into the genre, this may be the worst. While 'Poly Bridge'  lacks nothing in the graphic department, it quickly fails as a physics based bridge game. While most bridge building games use sound engineering principles as their guiding light, and increase the dificulty by setting budgets and locations of increasing dificulty, all the while leaving the possiblity of building a bridge that is both atractive and functional, Poly Bridge instead eshews this antiquated idea, and choses rather to give the user virtually impossible  obsticles to overcome, while saddling them with rediculous materials restrictions (an entirely wooden bridge, which must be piston lifted to allow a large ship through?) artificially limited materials budgets (you are allowed 4 road bed pieces in this map, while the shortest distance between the shores is 5 lengths, Don't wory, you'll find a way!) and downright agrivating scenareos. (build a wooden drawbridge across this gap. There is only one anchor point on the terrain in this map!)
The result is not bridges built on sound engineering principles, but rather deranged constructions, fabri-cobbled peicemeal from the ruins of society, designed to hurl vehicles across chasms, to barely survive the transit. While this sort of gameplay seems not out of place in Gary's Mod, or perhaps Lemings, it seems entirely out of place in the pastoral and placid setting of this gorgeous bridge game. This is the QWOP of bridge building games, Or perhaps the Flappy Bird of bridge building games. where your every instict tells you that it should be simple and fun, but the game has been deviously designed to be virtually impossible and unpleasent. Instead of a bridge building game, it is a carefully designed sanity eliminator.
